metadata.case_name: Nathoo Lal v. Plaintiff (son of Mst. Bhuri)

facts.text: Property originally belonged to Ramchandra who died sonless in 1903, survived by mother Sheokori, widow Mst. Badni, and daughters Bhuri and Laxmi.
Ramchandra made an oral will bequeathing the property to daughter Laxmi.
On 6th September 1906, Mst. Sheokori and Mst. Badni executed and registered a deed of gift of the property to Mst. Laxmi purporting to act per oral will.
Gift deed recitals: houses gifted according to will of father Ramchandra; he made gift to Laxmi and directed registration; no other claim; deal as you like; curses on reclaiming.
Widows had no title themselves; Sheokori joined execution though estate could not devolve on her.
Bhuri, second daughter, died in 1907.
Mst. Badni died in 1927.
Mst. Laxmi remained in possession till her death in 1928.
On 5th July 1930, Balabux (Laxmi's husband) mortgaged house to defendant appellant Nathoo Lal claiming as heir.
On 5th October 1933, Balabux sold house to Nathoo Lal and put him in possession; Nathoo Lal in possession since.
Plaintiff (son of Mst. Bhuri) filed suit in forma pauperis on 4th October 1945 for possession, one day before 12 years from defendant's entry.
Plaintiff alleged possession till 24th August 1933 through tenant; tenant vacated, he locked house, went to native village Harmara; learnt on 27th September 1944 that defendant took possession.
Plaintiff claimed Balabux had no right to mortgage/sell; Laxmi had only limited estate, not absolute owner.
Plaintiff admitted in witness box: Ramchandra made will in favour of Laxmi; grandmothers got gift deed registered per will; Laxmi held possession till death; kept deponent as son, rents in his name.
28th August 1947: Civil Judge dismissed suit; Laxmi absolute owner, plaintiff no title, Balabux stridhan heir; suit within limitation.
15th April 1948: District Judge affirmed; widow executed deed per oral will, Laxmi absolute estate; suit within limitation.

High Court Jaipur (Second Appeal): allowed appeal, decreed plaintiff suit; plaintiff in possession till dispossessed 5 Oct 1933 even during Laxmi lifetime; oral will no proof of absolute interest, gift to female confers limited life estate, reverts to heirs.
3rd March 1949: Decree of Jaipur High Court.
Defendant applied for review; Jaipur HC defunct, heard by Rajasthan HC; partially allowed 5th April 1950, amended decree: plaintiff possession on payment Rs. 4000 for improvements/repairs.
Courts below found plaintiff in possession even during Laxmi lifetime and continued after; possession presumed continuous till dispossession.

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit was within limitation.
Whether oral will and gift deed conferred absolute estate on Laxmi or only limited life estate.
Maintainability of appeal: whether decree of 5 April 1950 appealable under Article 133.
Whether substantial question of law for certificate.

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit barred by limitation: plaintiff alleged possession till 24 Aug 1933 via tenant, locked house but no evidence of locking; possession discontinued then, suit after 12 years.
Laxmi acquired absolute title under father's oral will; High Court erred in holding need express words for absolute interest to female heir.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu Law; no presumption of limited estate for females

respondent_arguments.text: Appeal not maintainable: Jaipur State CPC no appeal from HC; review only on improvements, does not reopen 1949 decision.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Jaipur State Code of Civil Procedure

respondent_arguments.text: No certificate justified: no substantial question.
Ramchandra intended gift but could not register; property devolved to widow, her gift to Laxmi limited to her estate (life estate).
No evidence of oral will terms; gift to female heir presumes limited life interest.

court_reasoning.text: Overruled preliminary objection on maintainability: operative decree is 5 Apr 1950 by Rajasthan HC post-Constitution, appealable under Art 133; Jaipur CPC irrelevant.
Certificate justified: property value Rs 20,000; substantial question whether testamentary disposition to female heir confers limited estate absent evidence of absolute intent.
Suit within limitation: courts below unanimously found plaintiff in possession during/after Laxmi; presumption of continuity till dispossession even if no lock evidence.
Ramchandra bequeathed by oral will, not gift; admitted by plaintiff; gift deed executed per will; recitals show Laxmi to deal as she likes; intent to confer same title as testator.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Laxmi absolute owner; devolves to husband Balabux.

court_reasoning.text: No presumption of limited estate for Hindu female; words of amplitude suffice for absolute estate; criticised old Privy Council view; followed recent SC decision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No express power of alienation needed if words convey full ownership.

holdings.text: Oral will and gift deed conferred absolute estate on Laxmi; she absolute owner; property devolved to husband Balabux with full alienation rights; plaintiff no heir.
Appeal maintainable under Article 133; certificate proper.
No presumption that gift/will to Hindu female confers only limited estate absent express words; general principle of inheritance applies per Hindu Law and s.8 TPA.

precedents_cited.relevance: Old PC case holding bequest to daughter-in-law limited estate; later clarified no presumption.
No presumption one way/other for females; same as males if words absolute.
Settled no presumption of limited estate for Hindu female; words of amplitude suffice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mst. Kollani Kuar v. Luchmi Kuar
precedents_cited.relevance: Reasoning approved by PC; general inheritance principle.
Estate to man without express inheritance carries inheritance by Hindu Law.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Appeal maintainable; certificate for substantial question.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Embodies general principle of inheritance in grants.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court decree set aside; trial court decree dismissing plaintiff's suit restored.
outcome.relief_granted: Dismissal of suit in favour of defendant Nathoo Lal.

key_quotes.text: "These houses are made a gift to you according to the will of your father, Ramchandra... You deal with your house in any way you like."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Gift deed recitals showing intent for absolute ownership.

key_quotes.text: "Ramchandra had made a will in favour of Mst. Laxmi... Through this gift deed Mst. Laxmi held possession over it till she was alive."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner

key_quotes.text: "It may be taken to be quite settled that there is no warrant for the proposition of law that when a grant of an immovable property is made to a Hindu female, she does not get an absolute or alienable interest..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding rejecting presumption of limited estate.
